conclusion: Consider principles of shadow formation and relative positions of light source, objects, and ground.
Four objects cast shadows labeled A, B, C, and D on the ground.
Light source is positioned behind the objects, causing shadows to extend forward.
When light source moves forward, it changes the angle at which light hits the objects.
As light source moves closer to being directly above objects, shadows become shorter and move closer to base of objects.
Shadows will decrease in size as light source moves directly above objects.
Shadows will shift position on the ground, moving towards the base of the objects.
Shadow A will shrink and move closer to the mitten object.
Shadow B will become smaller and move towards the base of the stapler.
Shadow C will shrink and move closer to the bird's base.
Shadow D will decrease in size and move towards the peach itself.
When light source is directly above objects, shadows will be at their smallest and positioned directly beneath the objects.
As light source moves forward above objects, shadows A, B, C, and D will decrease in size and move closer to base of their respective objects.
